Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A model-based synthesis of Mid Atlantic Bight Pioneer Array data to infer across-shelf fluxes, frontal variability, and characteristics of the array
Award.AbstractNarration:
In support of the National Science Foundation Ocean Observatories Initiative, the objective of the proposed research is to provide a synthesis of all existing and future observations collected by the Pioneer Array in the Mid-Atlantic Bight. Observation impact and observation sensitivity calculations will be used to evaluate the observing array. Until now, this has been largely the domain of numerical weather prediction. The proposed research will yield a sequence of high quality circulation analyses for the Mid-Atlantic Bight that will shed new light on the relative role of instability, eddy fluxes and surface forcing in promoting cross-shelf exchange and in shaping the circulation of the region. The resulting circulation analyses will be made available on a web server at Rutgers University and will represent a valuable community resource. Model configurations from this project will be used to frame lectures for international summer schools addressing advanced methods in applied coastal ocean modeling and data assimilation to senior graduate students and early career scientists. The project will also train a graduate student.

The specific goals of the project are to: (i) compute retroactive and near real-time analyses of the ocean circulation in the domain spanned by the Pioneer Array using a state-of-the-art ocean model and data assimilation system; (ii) explore the dynamics of shelf exchange processes; and (iii) evaluate the Pioneer Array design using dynamically motivated metrics of the shelf circulation. The Pioneer Array observations will be synthesized using a multi-scale configuration of the Regional Ocean Modeling System and a 4-dimensional variational data assimilation system. Being directly constrained by the observations, the resulting 3-dimensional time-evolving circulation estimates will be more reliable than either the model or the observations considered in isolation. The circulation estimates are expected to span the period 2015-2018 and will provide a valuable and seamless multi-year and multi-scale ocean data set that will be used to explore the dynamics of shelf-break processes in the region including seasonal variability in cross-shelf fluxes associated with stratification, eddy fluxes, the formation of boundary layers, and the occurrence of episodic exchange events across the shelf-break. The ability of the moored and mobile components of the Pioneer Array to address specific science questions will be evaluated using a suite of sophisticated analysis tools that quantify the impact of individual observations and assets on specific circulation metrics that target the aforementioned physical processes. The complimentary suite of tools used will include observation impact and observation sensitivity calculations, identification of the array modes, and observing system simulation experiments

POR.DRECONTENT:
The patterns of three-dimensional, time-evolving physical ocean circulation (currents, sea level, temperature and salinity) in the environs of the Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) Pioneer Coastal Array in the Mid-Atlantic Bight (MAB) have been computed using a nested hydrodynamic model with data assimilation.

The Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS; myroms.org) was employed in a configuration with three 2-way nested grids that progressively refine resolution to zoom in on the Pioneer Array region. The grids advance in horizontal resolution from 7 km to 2.2 km to 700 m at the finest nest (Figure 1). The 7-km resolution outer "Doppio" grid is the same as that used in the IOOS MARACOOS operational forecast system that draws open boundary condition data from the CMEMS Mercator-Océan system. The inner “Array” model nest encompasses the location of the Pioneer Array moorings (with their vertically profiling salinity, temperature and velocity instruments) and the nominal sampling paths of autonomous gliders (that measure temperature and salinity as they slowly profile the full water column depth along their trajectories). The vertical coordinate in all three grids uses 40 terrain following levels that give approximately 1-2 m resolution in the surface mixed layer throughout the majority of the Pioneer Array region.

A primary goal of the project was to quantify the information content that a closely spaced mooring and glider data set such as OOI Pioneer adds to capturing the ocean submesoscale turbulence, versus using only a sparse set of sustained observations such as flow from the U.S. Integrated Ocean Observing System (IOOS) and satellites. This project was hampered somewhat by limitations in Pioneer data availability due to difficulties in meeting the OOI build-out schedule for instrument deployments and implementing the cyberinfrastructure system for data delivery to users.

Nevertheless, a robust data assimilation system was implemented using IOOS data from gliders and surface-current measuring HF-radars of the Mid Atlantic Regional Association Coastal Ocean Observing System (MARACOOS), moorings operated by the National Data Buoy Center (NDBC), Ecosystem Monitoring (EcoMon) voyages of the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), and data reported by Argo profiling floats, XBTs, drifting buoys and vessel underway thermo-salinograph to the Global Telecommunications System (GTS) of the National Weather Service, plus observations of sea level from 5 radar altimeter satellites and temperature from more than 10 microwave and infrared radiometers aboard polar-orbiting and geostationary satellites operated by international space agencies. Data from the Pioneer Array accessed in delayed mode provided valuable independent observations for evaluating model and data assimilation system performance.

Pioneer instrumentation deployments commenced early in 2014. For the period 2014-2017, observations were assimilated into the model during successive 3-day analysis intervals using the ROMS 4-dimensional variational (4DVar) data assimilation system. During each 3-day cycle the model initial conditions, surface forcing (wind stress and heat flux), and open boundary conditions were adjusted by the assimilation process to give the solution that minimized the mismatch between observations and model, but that still satisfied the governing equations of the ROMS model for conservation of mass, heat and salt. Being directly constrained by the observations, the ocean circulation estimates from the complete modeling system are more representative of the ocean state than either an unconstrained model or the observations considered in isolation. The nested model-based analyses offer a multi-year and multi-scale ocean reanalysis data set suited to exploring the dynamics of shelf-break processes in the central MAB region.

A key accomplishment of the project was the development of an observation impact analysis methodology that allows for calculating the contribution each individual observation makes when the 4DVAR data assimilation adjusts a scalar index that characterizes some feature of the circulation. The indices we used to demonstrate this capability were cross-shelf fluxes of heat and mass in the region of the Pioneer Array. By calculating statistics of impacts aggregated by observing platform, location, or other criteria, we can contrast the information content of, for example, glider observations versus satellites, and identify observation sites that are particularly impactful. In the case of cross-shelf heat fluxes, glider observations in the upper 100 m and lower 600-1000 m depths of the water column are particularly valuable, but so too are salinity observations near the sea surface. However, for a different circulation index such as mixed layer depth or stratification, the relative impacts shift both geographically and in terms of observation type and platform, highlighting the value of a diversified and widely distributed observing network for supporting multi-purpose data assimilative modeling systems.
